title: 115_s2511
content: The Commercial Engagement Through Ocean Technology Act of 2018, also known as the CENOTE Act of 2018, includes a table of contents outlining the sections of the Act. The CENOTE Act of 2018 includes definitions, coordination for assessment and acquisition of unmanned maritime systems by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, regular assessments, acquisition procedures, reports on system usage, and funding provisions. The CENOTE Act of 2018 defines key terms and authorities for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, including funding and cooperative activities with external entities. The CENOTE Act of 2018 defines key terms for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, including cooperative activities with external entities and data specifications. The term "data specifications" in the CENOTE Act of 2018 refers to the type, resolution, periodicity, and quality of data required by an Administration program. The term "test or training range" designates areas for operating unmanned maritime systems and evaluating their performance or training personnel on operating procedures. The term "test or training range" includes specialized instrumentation for unmanned maritime systems. Unmanned maritime systems are remotely operated or autonomous vehicles designed to function without human presence. Unmanned maritime systems are remotely operated or autonomous vehicles designed to function without human presence, including unmanned undersea vehicles, unmanned surface vehicles, autonomous underwater vehicles, and autonomous surface vehicles. The term "unmanned maritime systems" includes unmanned undersea vehicles, unmanned surface vehicles, autonomous underwater vehicles, autonomous surface vehicles, unmanned aerial vehicles, and autonomous aerial vehicles used for maritime purposes. Coordination regarding assessment and acquisition by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of these systems is addressed in the Act. The Administrator will coordinate the Administration's research, assessment, and acquisition of unmanned maritime systems to achieve the purposes of the Act. This includes considering the use of unmanned maritime systems in cooperative activities. The Administrator will coordinate the Administration's research, assessment, and acquisition of unmanned maritime systems through the Unmanned Systems Executive Oversight Board (USEOB) to address requirements throughout the Administration. The Administrator will utilize the Unmanned Systems Executive Oversight Board (USEOB) to coordinate the Administration's unmanned maritime systems efforts and ensure representation from specific offices actively engaged with such systems. The Administrator will coordinate with the Navy to leverage expertise in unmanned maritime systems development and align with specific offices engaged in such systems. The Navy will utilize expertise in unmanned maritime systems development, align with specific offices, utilize test ranges, and promote interagency cooperation. The Navy will formalize coordination with the Secretary of the Navy to incorporate Administration priorities into research and development activities. The Secretary of the Navy will coordinate with the Administration to integrate priorities into research and development activities, partner on unmanned maritime systems procurement, and access Naval facilities for testing and training purposes. The Administrator will work with the Navy to access test ranges and facilities for various purposes, including mapping and ocean exploration. Activities authorized by this Act should ideally be carried out at a co-located facility. The Administrator and the Navy aim to collaborate at a co-located facility to advance unmanned maritime systems development, testing, modifications, integration, and accelerate the transition from concept to manufacturing and acquisition. The Administrator and the Secretary of the Navy may utilize the National Oceanographic Partnership Program for interagency coordination in advancing unmanned maritime systems. Coordination with the academic sector is also emphasized in the Act. The National Oceanographic Partnership Program, established for interagency coordination in advancing unmanned maritime systems, may coordinate with academic research institutions for research, development, and training in unmanned maritime systems. The National Oceanographic Partnership Program aims to maximize research and development opportunities for unmanned maritime systems, provide training in this field, facilitate commercialization through partnerships, and arrange access to facilities for testing and training under various environmental conditions. The National Oceanographic Partnership Program aims to maximize research and development opportunities for unmanned maritime systems, provide training, facilitate commercialization through partnerships, and arrange access to facilities for testing and training under various environmental conditions. This includes supporting testing, assessment, and training for unmanned maritime systems, engaging with academic institutions with relevant expertise, and promoting information sharing between academic, environmental, and military institutions. The National Oceanographic Partnership Program aims to support research and development of unmanned maritime systems by engaging with academic institutions and promoting information sharing. Additionally, it seeks to facilitate collaboration with the private sector to commercialize these systems. The National Oceanographic Partnership Program aims to support the commercialization of unmanned maritime systems by coordinating with the private sector. The Administrator will regularly assess commercially available unmanned maritime systems to support the missions of the Navy and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The Administrator will regularly assess publicly and commercially available unmanned maritime systems to support National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration missions. This will be done through the Assistant Administrator for Oceanic and Atmospheric Research and the Director of the Office of Marine and Aviation Operations. The Administrator will assess unmanned maritime systems for potential use to support NOAA missions. This will be done through science-based assessments by the Assistant Administrator and operational utility assessments by the Director. The Administrator will assess unmanned maritime systems for operational reliability, feasibility, and cost-effectiveness through the Director. The Assistant Administrator and Director will engage with various stakeholders to evaluate the use of unmanned maritime systems. The Technology Coordinating Committee will consult with various stakeholders to assess unmanned maritime systems. The Administrator will centralize the acquisition of these systems to meet data requirements identified by OAR and OMAO. Memoranda of Understanding will be established to enhance collaboration. The Administration will acquire unmanned maritime systems to meet data requirements identified by OAR and OMAO. A memorandum of agreement may be developed with the Secretary of the Navy for collaboration in procurements, accepting decommissioned systems, and sharing policies and procedures. The Administrator will acquire unmanned maritime systems to meet data requirements. The memorandum of understanding allows participation in procurements, accepting decommissioned systems, sharing policies, and creating efficiency in Federal acquisition. This Act does not modify Federal procurement law. The Administrator shall report on unmanned maritime systems and their usage for NOAA's mission. The Administrator will report on the usage of unmanned maritime systems for NOAA's mission every four years, including an inventory of current systems used. The report submitted under subsection (a) will include an inventory of current unmanned maritime systems used by the Administration, data summary, benefits realized, prioritized data requirements, and commercially available unmanned maritime systems. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" is defined in this section. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" is defined in this section as specific committees from the Senate and House of Representatives. The Administrator will carry out the Act using funding provided. SEC. 7. FUNDING AND ADDITIONAL AUTHORITIES. The Administrator will use existing funds for this Act and may enter into contracts, accept donations, and provide uncompensated services. The Administrator has the authority to enter contracts, accept donations, and receive funds from other Federal departments and agencies. They can also utilize the National Oceanographic Partnership Program for funding and partnerships. The Administrator, established under chapter 665 of title 10, United States Code, has the authority to accept funds, donations, enter contracts, transfer funds, and utilize resources from various government entities. The Administrator can utilize resources from various government entities, subject to availability of appropriations, including land, services, equipment, personnel, and facilities from US departments, State/local/tribal governments, or foreign governments/international organizations. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
